title: 108_s196
content: The "Minority Serving Institution Digital and Wireless Technology Opportunity Act of 2003" establishes an Office within the National Science Foundation to support eligible institutions in providing instruction in digital and wireless network technologies. This includes grants, contracts, or cooperative agreements to enhance national investment in telecommunications and technology infrastructure. An eligible institution can use funding to acquire equipment, develop educational services, provide teacher education, and implement joint projects related to technology in the classroom. The curr_chunk discusses the various ways in which funding can be utilized by different organizations to support technology education, including providing professional development, technical assistance, fostering the use of information technology, and developing proposals. The curr_chunk focuses on developing proposals and strategic plans for information technology investments under the Act. SEC. 4. APPLICATION AND REVIEW PROCEDURE. To be eligible for funding under this Act, eligible institutions must submit an application to the Director, who will establish a procedure for reviewing applications with input from an advisory council. The council will advise on involving institutions in program activities and evaluating proposals. The advisory council for the program includes representatives from technology and telecommunications institutions, minority businesses, eligible institution communities, Federal agency personnel, and individuals knowledgeable about technology issues. Panel reviewing proposals must include members from minority serving institutions. Program review criteria consider demonstrated need for assistance and diversity among institutions. Eligible institutions receiving funding must provide relevant institutional data to the Office. The Director will convene an annual meeting of eligible institutions to foster collaboration, capacity-building activities, and disseminate information generated by the meetings. SEC. 5. MATCHING REQUIREMENT. The Director may not award a grant, contract, or cooperative agreement to an eligible institution under this Act unless the institution agrees to provide non-Federal contributions equal to 1/4 of the amount awarded by the Director or $500,000, whichever is less. The matching requirement may be waived for institutions with no endowment or an endowment valued below $50,000,000. SEC. 6. LIMITATIONS. SEC. 6. LIMITATIONS. An eligible institution receiving a grant over $2,500,000 cannot receive another grant until all other eligible institutions have been awarded. Awards must be administered by the eligible institution. SEC. 7. ANNUAL REPORT AND EVALUATION. Each institution receiving a grant must provide an annual report on its use of the funding. The Director will evaluate the program every 2 years based on these reports, assessing the impact on students, faculty, and staff. A report will be submitted to Congress. The Director will evaluate the program every 2 years based on annual reports from grant-receiving institutions. A report with recommendations on the need for Federal support will be submitted to Congress. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, an eligible institution is defined as a historically Black college or university, a Hispanic-serving institution, or a tribally controlled college or university. The Director of the National Science Foundation determines institutions eligible for assistance based on enrollment of minority and low-income students who received aid under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The National Science Foundation determines eligibility for assistance based on enrollment of minority and low-income students who received aid under the Higher Education Act of 1965, including HUBZone small business concerns. Authorization of appropriations of $250,000,000 for each fiscal year 2004-2008 to the National Science Foundation for Act implementation.
